elements.content: In this article, Co-based metal organic frameworks (MOFs) with two shapes were used as pyrolysis precursor to synthesize multilayer core–shells composites loaded on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) sheets. The core–shell structures were obtained by the formation of cores from metal ions and carbon shells from carbonization of ligands. Controllable oxidation of Co cores to CoO x shells generated multilayer core–shell structures anchored onto the surface of rGO sheets. The N-doped composites were obtained by adding poly vinylpyrrolidone. The multilayer core–shells composites exhibited superior catalytic activity toward hydrogen generation compared to their single layer counterparts. By using the N-doped multilayer composites, high hydrogen generation specific rate of 5560 mL min–1 gCo –1 was achieved at room temperature. The rGO sheets in composites improved their structure stability. These catalysts exhibited high stability after used five cycling. This synergistic strategy proposes simple, efficient, and versatile blue-prints for the fabrication of rGO composites from MOFs-based precursors.
elements.clean_text: In this article, Co-based metal organic frameworks (MOFs) with two shapes were used as pyrolysis precursor to synthesize multilayer core-shells composites loaded on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) sheets. The core-shell structures were obtained by the formation of cores from metal ions and carbon shells from carbonization of ligands. Controllable oxidation of Co cores to CoO x  shells generated multilayer core-shell structures anchored onto the surface of rGO sheets. The N-doped composites were obtained by adding poly vinylpyrrolidone. The multilayer core-shells composites exhibited superior catalytic activity toward hydrogen generation compared to their single layer counterparts. By using the N-doped multilayer composites, high hydrogen generation specific rate of 5560 mL min-1 gCo -1 was achieved at room temperature. The rGO sheets in composites improved their structure stability. These catalysts exhibited high stability after used five cycling. This synergistic strategy proposes simple, efficient, and versatile blue-prints for the fabrication of rGO composites from MOFs-based precursors.

elements.content:
This paper was published on the Web on June 8, 2016, with minor errors in the Supporting Information. The corrected version was reposted on June 10, 2016.

Introduction

Core–shell structured nanocomposites (CSNCs) have become a hotspot in research of composite materials because of their unique physical and chemical properties and wide application prospects. CSNCs generally are composed of the center cores and outer over coating shells. As cores, the nanoparticles (NPs) with high specific surface area and surface energy provide high catalytic properties. The outer shells protect core NPs from agglomerating and enhance the structural stability of composite materials. These features ensure that CSNCs become ideal high performance catalysts in wide applications. The preparation of monodispersed core–shells with controllable shell thickness often is very difficult. The relationship between morphology and property needs further revelation, and the combination of strength and compatibility problem between layers also needs more research. Up to now, the core–shell composites have been researched mainly in laboratories but are not adopted in present industry.

Introduction

Core-shell structured nanocomposites (CSNCs) have become a hotspot in research of composite materials because of their unique physical and chemical properties and wide application prospects. CSNCs generally are composed of the center cores and outer over coating shells. As cores, the nanoparticles (NPs) with high specific surface area and surface energy provide high catalytic properties. The outer shells protect core NPs from agglomerating and enhance the structural stability of composite materials. These features ensure that CSNCs become ideal high performance catalysts in wide applications. The preparation of monodispersed core-shells with controllable shell thickness often is very difficult. The relationship between morphology and property needs further revelation, and the combination of strength and compatibility problem between layers also needs more research. Up to now, the core-shell composites have been researched mainly in laboratories but are not adopted in present industry.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are attracting increasing attention as a kind of materials composed of metal ions and organic ligands with porous crystalline structures. MOFs possess adjustable and diverse ordered skeletal structure with modifiable surface. MOFs are used as adsorbents in gas adsorption and separation and as carrier for metal NPs in heterogeneous catalysis. In recent years, because of their highly porous ordered structure, MOFs have been used to prepare some porous carbon materials with high specific surface area through metal catalyzed thermal pyrolysis with confine effect of organic ligands, which were tentatively applied into energy conversion and storage areas. Some new nanocomposite structures composed of metal or metal oxide and carbon matrix or carbon shells can be prepared from MOFs after thermal treatments.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are attracting increasing attention as a kind of materials composed of metal ions and organic ligands with porous crystalline structures. MOFs possess adjustable and diverse ordered skeletal structure with modifiable surface. MOFs are used as adsorbents in gas adsorption and separation and as carrier for metal NPs in heterogeneous catalysis. In recent years, because of their highly porous ordered structure, MOFs have been used to prepare some porous carbon materials with high specific surface area through metal catalyzed thermal pyrolysis with confine effect of organic ligands, which were tentatively applied into energy conversion and storage areas. Some new nanocomposite structures composed of metal or metal oxide and carbon matrix or carbon shells can be prepared from MOFs after thermal treatments.

elements.content: Hydrogen as a clean energy has attracted wide attention. It also is one of the most important industrial gases. NaBH4 is highly stable in alkaline solution, and the hydrolysis reaction of NaBH4 solution can occur to release hydrogen with the appropriate catalyst as follows: NaBH 4 + 2 H 2 O → Catalyst 4 H 2 + NaBO 2 ⁣ Δ H = − 75 kJ mol − 1

elements.content: According to the type reaction, 1 mol of NaBH4 and 2 mol of H2O can generate 4 mol of H2. With high hydrogen storage density, NaBH4 can be considered to produce hydrogen with high purity. The hydrogen generation is quickly improved only when NaBH4 solution is in contact with catalyst. This reaction is an appropriate probe to evaluate the catalytic properties of novel heterogeneous catalysts.

elements.content: Some MOFs are directly used as precursor for hydrogen generation with moderate catalytic activity. Core–shell structures can be loaded on graphene or reduced graphene oxide (rGO) sheets to enhance their physical properties. However, MOFs materials were very rarely loaded on graphene. Some core–shell structure of MOFs shells and metal or metal oxide cores were synthesized for improved performances. MOFs with controllable shapes and high carbon contents can be used to make core–shell structure through thermal pyrolysis. Those metals or metal oxides NPs generated from metal ions will be covered with closed or open carbon layer shells from organic ligands in thermal pyrolysis. The carbon shells were wrapped mostly by glucose hydrothermal approach, so the multilayer core–shell structures are not easy to be controllably synthesized with clear carbon shell structure. By using Co-MOFs as pyrolysis precursor, core–shell structures of Co cores and carbon shells may be synthesized in one-step reaction. Because the single metal NPs do not usually provide the best catalytic property, some metal–metal oxide junctions often are desired for synergistic effects at the interfaces. The interfaces of Co and CoO x can be fabricated through controllable oxidation of Co cores for excellent catalytic activity in hydrogen generation from the hydrolysis of NaBH4.

elements.content: In this article, Co@carbon and Co@carbon-rGO composites were obtained through pyrolysis of various Co-MOF in annealing process. Controllable oxidation created Co@CoO x @carbon-rGO as multilayer core–shells structures. Compared to these single-layer counterparts, these multilayer core–shells structures exhibited much higher catalytic activity in hydrogen generation through hydrolysis of NaBH4. The improved catalytic performances should be due to the synergy effect between Co and CoO x . The core–shell structures also strengthened the structure stability in catalytic reaction processes. The magnetism of Co cores assisted the magnetic momentum transfer efficiency.

elements.content: Graphite oxide was synthesized used a modified Hummer’s method. Graphite oxide (300 mg) was dispersed into ethanol (200 mL) to form a suspension of graphene oxide (GO) under ultrasonic bath with agitating for 2 h. An ethanol solution (30 mL) of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (10 mmol, 2.90 g) and poly vinylpyrrolidone (PVP) (1.00 g) was added dropwise into the suspension of GO, and then the mixture was stirred for further 4 h. An ethanol solution (30 mL) of terephthalic acid (10 mmol, 1.66 g) was added dropwise into the above mixture, stirred for 10 min, and then ultrasonic treated for 30 min. The mixture was transported into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (500 mL) and kept at 100 °C for 60 h. After being cooled to room temperature, Co-MOF-GO was obtained as black powder. For comparison, Co-MOF was synthesized as a needle-liked purple crystal by a similar protocol in the absence of GO and PVP. Co-MOF-GO was synthesized as black powder by a similar protocol without the addition of PVP. Co-MOF-PVP was synthesized as a flesh pink powder by a similar protocol without the addition of GO (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Preparation of Materials

Graphite oxide was synthesized used a modified Hummer's method. Graphite oxide (300 mg) was dispersed into ethanol (200 mL) to form a suspension of graphene oxide (GO) under ultrasonic bath with agitating for 2 h. An ethanol solution (30 mL) of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (10 mmol, 2.90 g) and poly vinylpyrrolidone (PVP) (1.00 g) was added dropwise into the suspension of GO, and then the mixture was stirred for further 4 h. An ethanol solution (30 mL) of terephthalic acid (10 mmol, 1.66 g) was added dropwise into the above mixture, stirred for 10 min, and then ultrasonic treated for 30 min. The mixture was transported into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (500 mL) and kept at 100 °C for 60 h. After being cooled to room temperature, Co-MOF-GO was obtained as black powder. For comparison, Co-MOF was synthesized as a needle-liked purple crystal by a similar protocol in the absence of GO and PVP. Co-MOF-GO was synthesized as black powder by a similar protocol without the addition of PVP. Co-MOF-PVP was synthesized as a flesh pink powder by a similar protocol without the addition of GO (Figure S1).

elements.content: Co-MOF, Co-MOF-GO, Co-MOF-PVP, and Co-MOF-PVP-GO were heated to 700 °C with a ramp of 5 °C min–1 in N2 flow and then kept for 1 h. After being slowly cooled to room temperature, black composites were obtained and denoted as Co@carbon (Co@C), Co@carbon-rGO (Co@CG), Co@N-carbon (Co@N–C), and Co@N-carbon-rGO (Co@N-CG), respectively.

After being slowly cooled to room temperature, black composites were obtained and denoted as Co@carbon (Co@C), Co@carbon-rGO (Co@CG), Co@N-carbon (Co@N-C), and Co@N-carbon-rGO (Co@N-CG), respectively.

elements.content: Co@C, Co@CG, Co@C–N, and Co@C-NG were kept at 200 °C for 24 h in enough air. Black composites were obtained and denoted as Co@CoO x @carbon (Co@CoO x @C), Co@CoO x @carbon-rGO (Co@CoO x @CG), Co@CoO x @N-carbon (Co@CoO x @N–C), and Co@CoO x @N-carbon-rGO (Co@CoO x @N-CG), respectively.

Black composites were obtained and denoted as Co@CoO x @carbon (Co@CoO x @C), Co@CoO x @carbon-rGO (Co@CoO x @CG), Co@CoO x @N-carbon (Co@CoO x @N-C), and Co@CoO x @N-carbon-rGO (Co@CoO x @N-CG), respectively.

elements.content: The phase structure of as–prepared product was characterized with X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 advance with Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). The average crystallite size of Co NPs was estimated using the Scherrer formula: D h = λ/(βh × cos θ h ). D h is the domain size of the diffraction line, λ is the wavelength of the Cu Kα source used, βh is the width in radians of the diffraction peak measured at half-maximum intensity (full-width at half-maximum, fwhm) corrected for instrumental broadening, and θh is the angle of the particular hkl reflection. Raman spectrum was recorded on a Renishaw RM–1000 with excitation from the 514 nm line of an Ar–ion laser with a power of about 5 mW. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra measurements were carried out on a NICOLET 380 Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a PHI quantera SXM spectrometer with an Al Kα = 280.00 eV excitation source, where binding energies were calibrated by referencing the C 1s peak (284.8 eV) to reduce the sample charge effect. The morphology of as-prepared product was studied by using transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN electron microscope, operating at 200 kV). The N2 sorption isotherms were measured on NOVA 1000e surface area and poresize analyzer (Quantachrome Instrument, USA) at 77 K. From the adsorption branch of isotherm curves in the P/P 0 range between 0.05 and 0.35, the specific surface areas (S BET) of Co@CoO x @C-XX are calculated by the multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore size distribution was evaluated by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model. The total pore volume (V total) was determined from the amount adsorbed at the relative pressure of about 0.99. For the analysis of the magnetic material of the hysteresis loop used for the PPMS-9T-type physical magnetic test system, the temperature was 300 K, and the magnetic field strength is −40–40 kOe, plus field cooling (FC) and zero field cooling (ZFC) response curve (magnetic field 100 Oe). Elemental analysis (EA) is The Thermo Flash EA 1112.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

The phase structure of as-prepared product was characterized with X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 advance with Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). The average crystallite size of Co NPs was estimated using the Scherrer formula: D h = λ/(βh × cos θ h ). D h is the domain size of the diffraction line, λ is the wavelength of the Cu Kα source used, βh is the width in radians of the diffraction peak measured at half-maximum intensity (full-width at half-maximum, fwhm) corrected for instrumental broadening, and θh is the angle of the particular hkl reflection. Raman spectrum was recorded on a Renishaw RM-1000 with excitation from the 514 nm line of an Ar-ion laser with a power of about 5 mW. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra measurements were carried out on a NICOLET 380 Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a PHI quantera SXM spectrometer with an Al Kα = 280.00 eV excitation source, where binding energies were calibrated by referencing the C 1s peak (284.8 eV) to reduce the sample charge effect. The morphology of as-prepared product was studied by using transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN electron microscope, operating at 200 kV). The N2 sorption isotherms were measured on NOVA 1000e surface area and poresize analyzer (Quantachrome Instrument, USA) at 77 K. From the adsorption branch of isotherm curves in the P/P 0 range between 0.05 and 0.35, the specific surface areas (S BET) of Co@CoO x @C-XX are calculated by the multipoint Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The pore size distribution was evaluated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. The total pore volume (V total) was determined from the amount adsorbed at the relative pressure of about 0.99. For the analysis of the magnetic material of the hysteresis loop used for the PPMS-9T-type physical magnetic test system, the temperature was 300 K, and the magnetic field strength is -40-40 kOe, plus field cooling (FC) and zero field cooling (ZFC) response curve (magnetic field 100 Oe). Elemental analysis (EA) is The Thermo Flash EA 1112.

elements.content: Hydrogen generation was studied with the typical water displacement method. Catalyst (20 mg) was placed in a round-bottom glass flask. Then the aqueous NaOH (5 wt%, 20 mL) solution of NaBH4 (80 mg) was injected through constant pressure drop funnel. The flask was placed on a magnetic stirrer. In magneton-stirring mode, a magneton was employed in the flask. In self-stirring mode, only catalyst and reaction mixture were loaded in the flask. The stirring rate was fixed at 500 rpm, and other stirring rates were used only if noted. An inverted and water-filled gas buret in a water-filled vessel was used to monitor the volume of the evolved H2 (Figure S2). The hydrogen generation specific rates were calculated using the information in the initiating and stabilizing stages (140 mL of hydrogen generated) according the following formula: r B = 80 ( mL ) [ t 140 − t 60 ] ( min ) × w c ( g ) Here, r B is the hydrogen generation specific rate, t 140 represents the time for 140 mL of hydrogen generation, and t 60 for 60 mL, and w c is the Co weight in catalyst.
elements.clean_text: Hydrogen generation was studied with the typical water displacement method. Catalyst (20 mg) was placed in a round-bottom glass flask. Then the aqueous NaOH (5 wt%, 20 mL) solution of NaBH4 (80 mg) was injected through constant pressure drop funnel. The flask was placed on a magnetic stirrer. In magneton-stirring mode, a magneton was employed in the flask. In self-stirring mode, only catalyst and reaction mixture were loaded in the flask. The stirring rate was fixed at 500 rpm, and other stirring rates were used only if noted. An inverted and water-filled gas buret in a water-filled vessel was used to monitor the volume of the evolved H2 (Figure S2). The hydrogen generation specific rates were calculated using the information in the initiating and stabilizing stages (140 mL of hydrogen generated) according the following formula: 2      r   B   =   80   ( mL )     [   t   140   -   t   60   ]    ( min )  ×   w   c     ( g )      Here, r B is the hydrogen generation specific rate, t 140 represents the time for 140 mL of hydrogen generation, and t 60 for 60 mL, and w c is the Co weight in catalyst.

elements.content: The designed composites were constructed by synthesizing core–shell structures and anchoring them onto the surface of rGO sheets in thermal pyrolysis processes, as described above (). In MOF synthesis process, MOFs precursors were obtained from Co ions and terephthalic acid (TPA) and deposited onto the surface of rGO sheets in the presence of GO. In the subsequent solvothermal treatment, the formation of MOFs and reduction of GO were carried out synchronously. A thermal pyrolysis was performed under a nitrogen atmosphere. Co ions in Co-MOFs were transformed to Co NPs by those carbon generated from ligands. The excess carbon was wrapped on Co NPs as outer shells catalyzed by those Co NPs. The single core–shell structures and corresponding composites onto rGO have been formed as Co@CG and Co@N-CG in pyrolysis processes. After thermal treatment at 200 °C in air, part of Co(0) on the surface of Co NPs was oxidized to CoO x to form the first layer shells wrapped over the surface of Co cores; meanwhile, carbon shells became the second layer shells. After these processing steps, Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG were successfully fabricated. Co@CoO x @C and Co@CoO x @N–C were obtained through the same process in the absence of GO.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The designed composites were constructed by synthesizing core-shell structures and anchoring them onto the surface of rGO sheets in thermal pyrolysis processes, as described above (). In MOF synthesis process, MOFs precursors were obtained from Co ions and terephthalic acid (TPA) and deposited onto the surface of rGO sheets in the presence of GO. In the subsequent solvothermal treatment, the formation of MOFs and reduction of GO were carried out synchronously. A thermal pyrolysis was performed under a nitrogen atmosphere. Co ions in Co-MOFs were transformed to Co NPs by those carbon generated from ligands. The excess carbon was wrapped on Co NPs as outer shells catalyzed by those Co NPs. The single core-shell structures and corresponding composites onto rGO have been formed as Co@CG and Co@N-CG in pyrolysis processes. After thermal treatment at 200 °C in air, part of Co(0) on the surface of Co NPs was oxidized to CoO x  to form the first layer shells wrapped over the surface of Co cores; meanwhile, carbon shells became the second layer shells. After these processing steps, Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG were successfully fabricated. Co@CoO x @C and Co@CoO x @N-C were obtained through the same process in the absence of GO.

elements.content: Illustration of the stepwise structure evolution from Co-MOFs composites to Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG.
elements.clean_text: 1  Illustration of the stepwise structure evolution from Co-MOFs composites to Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG.

elements.content: The microstructures of Co-MOF, Co-MOF-GO, Co-MOF-PVP, and Co-MOF-PVP-GO precursors were observed by TEM images (Figure S3). Co-MOF showed uniform flake-like and somewhat curled up together (Figure S3a,b). In Co-MOF-GO, flakes curled up together and covered uniformly on GO sheets (Figure S3c,d). Co-MOF-PVP also showed sheet-like because PVP prevented MOF from curling and maintained the flake shape (Figure S3e,f). Co-MOF-PVP-GO sheets covered uniformly on GO (Figure S3g,h). These MOFs precursors were used as catalysts for hydrogen generation from hydrolysis of NaBH4 (Figure S4a). Different MOFs composites exhibited somewhat catalytic activity for hydrogen generation with various moderate reaction rates. There was little positive effect on catalytic activity with NaOH (Figure S4b). In the reaction process, the MOFs composites gradually turned into black powder with significant magnetism due to the reduction effect of NaBH4. The XRD pattern of used composites presented the diffraction peaks at 44.2°, 51.5°, and 75.9°, corresponding to ferromagnetic Co(0) (Figure S4c). To obtain catalytic materials with higher activity, the thermal pyrolysis of MOFs precursors through annealing treatment should be necessary. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of Co-MOF-GO was performed in air and Ar atmosphere to demonstrate 700 °C as appropriate annealing temperature ().

elements.content: The existence of MOFs in composites also was demonstrated by the XRD patterns (a). In the XRD patterns of composites annealing at 700 °C, those diffraction peaks at 44.2° (111), 51.5° (200), 75.9° (220) were corresponded to Co(0) (b). In the pyrolysis process of MOFs, some reduction–oxidation reactions happened because of the oxidation property of metal ions and reduction property of organic ligands. The Co(0) exists as main metal component in products annealing at 700 °C. The catalytic performances of Co@CG and Co@N-CG for hydrogen generation from NaBH4 were investigated in batch reactor (Figure S5). These thermal pyrolysis products exhibited lower catalytic activity than those of MOFs composite precursors, without the desired positive effect (a). The peaks of composites located at 26.4° can prove that GO was reduced to rGO (d).

elements.content: In catalytic hydrogen generation, the composites containing Co(0) exhibited no good activity due to the unique nature of this catalytic reaction. To obtain excellent catalytic activity, further controls on components of catalysis were tentatively carried out by partial oxidation. After oxidation treatment, the diffraction peaks corresponding to Co(0) still exist, and the peaks at 42.4° (311) are corresponding to CoO x . No other crystal can be found from four composites (c). Co@CoO x @C, Co@CoO x @N–C, Co@CoO x @CG, and Co@CoO x @N-CG were obtained by annealing Co@C, Co@N–C, Co@CG, and Co@N-CG at 200 °C in air. Some Co(0) has been oxidized to CoO x and formed the first layer shells covered on the Co(0) cores. The carbon layers covered CoO x as the second layer shells, which is in agreement with the three-layer structure in HRTEM images (, S6, and S7). Multilayer core–shell structures are mainly anchored onto the surface or intercalated between the rGO sheets (a–d). The CoO x shells (d = 0.28 nm) were covered on the Co(0) cores (d = 0.21 nm). The second shells of C (d = 0.35 nm) were covered on the surface of CoO x .

Multilayer core-shell structures are mainly anchored onto the surface or intercalated between the rGO sheets (a-d). The CoO x  shells (d = 0.28 nm) were covered on the Co(0) cores (d = 0.21 nm). The second shells of C (d = 0.35 nm) were covered on the surface of CoO x .

elements.content: These features can be observed in the mapping of Co@CoO x @CG (). Carbon exists in most areas, indicating that the core–shell structures were loaded on the rGO sheets. Co(0) showed high concentration in the center region of every spheres and filled in the whole area of composites. Oxygen was distributed with partial cavity structure. It can be induced that these core–shell structures possessed Co(0) cores, the first layer CoO x shells and the outermost carbon shells. All of them showed that C formed from MOFs as the second shells is strong reductive. Although graphene showed extraordinary performances for nanodevices, intrinsic graphene had no energy gap. It is important for the introduction of energy gap to endow graphene with specific geometric configurations. The lineal scanning image of Co@CoOx@CG provides the strong proof (Figure S6g). The controllable graphene cutting technology has been becoming a research hotspot. It is noteworthy that CoO x NPs were observed to move on the surface of rGO sheets at 700 °C and left some straight cutting marks (Figure S6e,f). This interesting phenomenon may indicate a potential direction for the development of graphene cutting technology.

elements.content: In Raman spectra of GO, Co@CoO x @CG, and Co@CoO x @N-CG, the D bands at 1367 cm–1 were due to the disorder carbon caused by lattice defects (). The G bands at 1594 cm–1 represented the first-order scattering of the E2g vibrational mode within aromatic carbon rings. The calculated I D/I G intensity ratios of GO, Co@CoO x @CG, and Co@CoO x @N-CG were 0.8, 1, and 1, respectively, indicating that GO was reduced during the solvothermal process (a). The diffraction peaks at around 191, 466, 509, 600, and 670 cm–1 detected in Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG were ascribed to CoO x , which were assigned to the five Raman-active modes (A1g, Eg, and 3F2g) of CoO x (). It should be noted that the position of the A1g peak in Co@CoO x @CG (670 cm–1) was lower energy compared with that of Co@CoO x @N-CG (680 cm–1) because of the existence of trace N. Co@CoO x @C and Co@CoO x @N–C also showed the same phenomenon (a). All of them were in good agreement with those obtained from the XRD patterns.

elements.content: The surface composition of four composites was determined by XPS spectra. The C 1s peaks in Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG corresponded to CC (284.4 eV), C–O (285.05 eV), and OC (288.7 eV) bonds (a,b). The peaks of C–O and OC were very weak, which exhibited that GO is partially reduced during the solvothermal process. The possible formation of interfacial C–O–Co bonds is also suggested, which is responsible for anchoring CoO x . The O 1s peaks of Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG were divided into the CoO (529.69 eV), C–O (530.0 eV), and OC (532.74 eV), which proved that Co became CoO x after 200 °C at air (c,d). The main peaks centered at 285 eV, 530 eV, and 778–798 eV are attributed to C 1s, O 1s, and Co 2p in Co@CoO x @CG, respectively (g,h). The N 1s peak in Co@CoO x @N-CG is centered at 402 eV (h). The weak N 1s peak in Co@CoO x @N-CG accounts for the small amount of N in composite (Figure S8a,b). In Co@CoO x @C and Co@CoO x @N–C, it is similar to each other (e and S9a). The EA perfectly echoed the Raman and XPS spectra. The TGA curves of composites were measured in air atmosphere (Figure S10). The mass ratios of Co were calculated as 72%, 62%, 75%, and 67% for Co@CoO x @C, Co@CoO x @CG, Co@CoO x @N–C, and Co@CoO x @N-CG, respectively. By EA, the mass ratios of Co were calculated as 89%, 58%, 83%, and 64% for Co@CoO x @C, Co@CoO x @CG, Co@CoO x @N–C, and Co@CoO x @N-CG, respectively (Table S1). The relative atomic ratio proved that C is the main component, and Co is very little in surface, due to the core–shells structure (Table S2).

elements.content: The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG were measured by at 77 K (). The S BET values of 67 and 46 m2 g–1 were obtained for Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG with pore volumes of 0.2 and 0.1 cm3 g–1 between 15 and 300 nm. Such large specific surface areas were of importance for enhancing the catalyst activity. These textural properties were comparable to those of typical catalysts.

elements.content: The magnetization curves of Co@CoO x @CG were measured at 300 K in a variable applied field (a). The hysteresis loop of Co@CoO x @CG showed a coercive force (H c) of 480.97 Oe and remanent magnetization (M r) of 446.46 emu g–1 with a S r = M r/H c value of 0.93. These parameters were evidence for the ferromagnetism of Co@CoO x @CG (Figure S11). The ferromagnetism properties with strong magnetic response make Co@CoO x @CG are easily isolated from water mixing system (Figure S12). The ZFC and FC magnetization curves of Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG were measured with an applied field of 500 Oe (c,d). The Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG showed ferromagnetic properties in 2–219.4 K and 2–215.3 K due to the existence of ferromagnetic Co. In ZFC curves, Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG reached the maximum magnetization at 219.4 and 215.3 K, respectively. The weak temperature dependence of magnetism ensures Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG be easily used in a wide temperature range. The Co@CoO x @C and Co@CoO x @N–C showed similar performances (Figure S12).

elements.content: Herein, a new concept was introduced as magnetic momentum transfer. Magnetic momentum transfer is a new technology to achieve momentum transfer in a noncontact way through magnetic fields. The catalysts provided higher NaBH4 decomposition rates under the magnetic-driving self-stirring than under magnetic stirring at 500 rpm. This can be interpreted that the magneton adsorbs composite materials on its surface and hinders the catalyst to be dispersed in aqueous solution. The catalyst cannot be dispersed in solution, and the reaction rate reduces. The existence of NaOH can stabilize the reaction mixture, so the NaBH4 solution containing 5 wt% NaOH was chosen to investigate catalysis under self-stirring rate of 500 rpm (Figure S13a). Co@CG and Co@N-CG exhibited lower catalytic activity than Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG (Figure S13b). The two-layer shells are necessary for excellent catalytic performances. Compared to Co@CoO x @C and Co@CoO x @N–C, Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG showed higher catalytic activity (Figure S13).

elements.content: To investigate the catalytic effect under the different condition, the hydrogen generations were studied with different concentration under different stirring rates, respectively (Figure S14). Co@CoO x @C and Co@CoO x @N–C exhibited higher rates at 0.2 and 0.3 M than those at 0.05 and 0.1 M. With Co@CoO x @CG or Co@CoO x @N-CG as catalyst, the hydrogen generation specific rates do not significantly change in 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.3 M of solution of NaBH4, so they were stable catalytic activity at different concentrations (Figure S14a–d). To study under the effects of stirring rates, Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG were used with various stirring rate (Figure S14e,f). There was no significant change at 300, 500, and 700 rpm. At 100 rpm, the hydrogen generation specific rate decreased somewhat slowly with little change. The stirring rates showed no clear influence on the hydrogen generation specific rates in the self-stirring mode. Because of the magnetism of catalyst itself, the catalyst was attracted on the magneton under magneton stirring mode and reduced the disperse degree of catalyst in reaction solution (Figure S15). With Co@CoO x @CG or Co@CoO x @N-CG as catalyst, the somewhat low hydrogen generation specific rates were obtained under relative lower of magneton stirring rates.

elements.content:
Through linear slopes, the reaction activation energy values were calculated as 23.3, 25.8, 40.0, and 36.6 kJ mol–1 for Co@CoO x @C, Co@CoO x @N–C, Co@CoO x @CG, and Co@CoO x @N-CG, respectively.

The high r B values of 2140, 2435, 5560, and 3270 mL min–1 gCo –1 were calculated for Co@CoO x @C, Co@CoO x @N–C, Co@CoO x @CG, and Co@CoO x @N-CG at 303 K, respectively (a). With Co@CoO x @CG as optimized catalyst, the highest r B value of 17360 mL min–1 gCo –1 can be obtained at an elevated temperature of 328 K. The catalytic activity of Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG also exhibited obvious advantages compared to those of Co@CG and Co@N-CG at various temperatures (b). These catalytic activities are comparable to those in the literature (Table S3). The existences of CoO x shells, rGO sheets, and N-doping atoms in composites do improve the catalytic activity of composites due to the synergistic effect (a,b). Two composites showed excellent recyclability, even if being reused for five times, and the catalytic activity did not fade drastically (c,d). The composition and phase structure also were maintained well after being used (Figure S17). The weak decreasing catalytic activity of reused catalysts is mainly caused by the separation treatment in air atmosphere. These excellent catalytic properties ensure that the multilayer core–shells on sheets composites can be applied into some other reactions such as oxygen evolution reaction or oxygen reduction reaction. Generally, the thickness of shells in core–shell structures has a significant effect on catalytic activity due to the diffusion restriction in thick shells. The shell thick tuning will be studied in future work.

elements.content: In conclusion, Co-MOF and Co-MOF-rGO composites with various shapes were synthesized through solvent-thermal approach and used as precursors for pyrolysis processes. The Co@carbon and Co@carbon-rGO core–shell structures were obtained with the formation of cores from metal ions and carbon shells from carbonization of ligand molecules. Controllable oxidation of Co cores to Co shells generated multilayer core–shell structures, namely Co@CoO x @carbon. The core–shell composites can be anchored onto the surface of rGO sheets. The Co cores and CoO x shells exhibited somewhat interface interaction due to the nature of junctions. In hydrogen generation through hydrolysis of NaBH4, these core–shell structures exhibited superior catalytic performances. Compared to single core–shells, multilayer core–shells, Co@CoO x @carbon possessed higher catalytic activity with lower activation energy. The improved catalytic activity should be due to the synergy effects between Co and CoO x on the interfaces region. The carbon shells or N-doped carbon shells protected the Co or Co@CoO x cores from growing, aggregating, or breaking up for excellent stability. The rGO sheets facilitated the magnetic momentum transfer and improved the flexibility of these core–shells catalysts. This synthesis strategy will open an avenue for catalytic materials with various core–shells structures from MOFs precursors. These core–shells structures anchoring on rGO sheets may be used as an excellent alternative for the design of effective heterogeneous catalysts involving energy industrial routes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, Co-MOF and Co-MOF-rGO composites with various shapes were synthesized through solvent-thermal approach and used as precursors for pyrolysis processes. The Co@carbon and Co@carbon-rGO core-shell structures were obtained with the formation of cores from metal ions and carbon shells from carbonization of ligand molecules. Controllable oxidation of Co cores to Co shells generated multilayer core-shell structures, namely Co@CoO x @carbon. The core-shell composites can be anchored onto the surface of rGO sheets. The Co cores and CoO x  shells exhibited somewhat interface interaction due to the nature of junctions. In hydrogen generation through hydrolysis of NaBH4, these core-shell structures exhibited superior catalytic performances. Compared to single core-shells, multilayer core-shells, Co@CoO x @carbon possessed higher catalytic activity with lower activation energy. The improved catalytic activity should be due to the synergy effects between Co and CoO x  on the interfaces region. The carbon shells or N-doped carbon shells protected the Co or Co@CoO x  cores from growing, aggregating, or breaking up for excellent stability. The rGO sheets facilitated the magnetic momentum transfer and improved the flexibility of these core-shells catalysts. This synthesis strategy will open an avenue for catalytic materials with various core-shells structures from MOFs precursors. These core-shells structures anchoring on rGO sheets may be used as an excellent alternative for the design of effective heterogeneous catalysts involving energy industrial routes.

cln_elements.content:
Graphite oxide was synthesized used a modified Hummer’s method. Graphite oxide (300 mg) was dispersed into ethanol (200 mL) to form a suspension of graphene oxide (GO) under ultrasonic bath with agitating for 2 h. An ethanol solution (30 mL) of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (10 mmol, 2.90 g) and poly vinylpyrrolidone (PVP) (1.00 g) was added dropwise into the suspension of GO, and then the mixture was stirred for further 4 h. An ethanol solution (30 mL) of terephthalic acid (10 mmol, 1.66 g) was added dropwise into the above mixture, stirred for 10 min, and then ultrasonic treated for 30 min. The mixture was transported into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (500 mL) and kept at 100 °C for 60 h. After being cooled to room temperature, Co-MOF-GO was obtained as black powder. For comparison, Co-MOF was synthesized as a needle-liked purple crystal by a similar protocol in the absence of GO and PVP. Co-MOF-GO was synthesized as black powder by a similar protocol without the addition of PVP. Co-MOF-PVP was synthesized as a flesh pink powder by a similar protocol without the addition of GO (Figure S1).

Co-MOF, Co-MOF-GO, Co-MOF-PVP, and Co-MOF-PVP-GO were heated to 700 °C with a ramp of 5 °C min–1 in N2 flow and then kept for 1 h. After being slowly cooled to room temperature, black composites were obtained and denoted as Co@carbon (Co@C), Co@carbon-rGO (Co@CG), Co@N-carbon (Co@N–C), and Co@N-carbon-rGO (Co@N-CG), respectively.

Hydrogen generation was studied with the typical water displacement method. Catalyst (20 mg) was placed in a round-bottom glass flask. Then the aqueous NaOH (5 wt%, 20 mL) solution of NaBH4 (80 mg) was injected through constant pressure drop funnel. The flask was placed on a magnetic stirrer. In magneton-stirring mode, a magneton was employed in the flask. In self-stirring mode, only catalyst and reaction mixture were loaded in the flask. The stirring rate was fixed at 500 rpm, and other stirring rates were used only if noted. An inverted and water-filled gas buret in a water-filled vessel was used to monitor the volume of the evolved H2 (Figure S2). The hydrogen generation specific rates were calculated using the information in the initiating and stabilizing stages (140 mL of hydrogen generated) according the following formula: r B = 80 ( mL ) [ t 140 − t 60 ] ( min ) × w c ( g ) Here, r B is the hydrogen generation specific rate, t 140 represents the time for 140 mL of hydrogen generation, and t 60 for 60 mL, and w c is the Co weight in catalyst.

Experimental Section

Preparation of Materials

Graphite oxide was synthesized used a modified Hummer's method. Graphite oxide (300 mg) was dispersed into ethanol (200 mL) to form a suspension of graphene oxide (GO) under ultrasonic bath with agitating for 2 h. An ethanol solution (30 mL) of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (10 mmol, 2.90 g) and poly vinylpyrrolidone (PVP) (1.00 g) was added dropwise into the suspension of GO, and then the mixture was stirred for further 4 h. An ethanol solution (30 mL) of terephthalic acid (10 mmol, 1.66 g) was added dropwise into the above mixture, stirred for 10 min, and then ultrasonic treated for 30 min. The mixture was transported into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (500 mL) and kept at 100 °C for 60 h. After being cooled to room temperature, Co-MOF-GO was obtained as black powder. For comparison, Co-MOF was synthesized as a needle-liked purple crystal by a similar protocol in the absence of GO and PVP. Co-MOF-GO was synthesized as black powder by a similar protocol without the addition of PVP. Co-MOF-PVP was synthesized as a flesh pink powder by a similar protocol without the addition of GO (Figure S1).

Co-MOF, Co-MOF-GO, Co-MOF-PVP, and Co-MOF-PVP-GO were heated to 700 °C with a ramp of 5 °C min-1 in N2 flow and then kept for 1 h. After being slowly cooled to room temperature, black composites were obtained and denoted as Co@carbon (Co@C), Co@carbon-rGO (Co@CG), Co@N-carbon (Co@N-C), and Co@N-carbon-rGO (Co@N-CG), respectively.

Hydrogen generation was studied with the typical water displacement method. Catalyst (20 mg) was placed in a round-bottom glass flask. Then the aqueous NaOH (5 wt%, 20 mL) solution of NaBH4 (80 mg) was injected through constant pressure drop funnel. The flask was placed on a magnetic stirrer. In magneton-stirring mode, a magneton was employed in the flask. In self-stirring mode, only catalyst and reaction mixture were loaded in the flask. The stirring rate was fixed at 500 rpm, and other stirring rates were used only if noted. An inverted and water-filled gas buret in a water-filled vessel was used to monitor the volume of the evolved H2 (Figure S2). The hydrogen generation specific rates were calculated using the information in the initiating and stabilizing stages (140 mL of hydrogen generated) according the following formula: 2      r   B   =   80   ( mL )     [   t   140   -   t   60   ]    ( min )  ×   w   c     ( g )      Here, r B is the hydrogen generation specific rate, t 140 represents the time for 140 mL of hydrogen generation, and t 60 for 60 mL, and w c is the Co weight in catalyst.

cln_elements.content:
The phase structure of as–prepared product was characterized with X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 advance with Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). The average crystallite size of Co NPs was estimated using the Scherrer formula: D h = λ/(βh × cos θ h ). D h is the domain size of the diffraction line, λ is the wavelength of the Cu Kα source used, βh is the width in radians of the diffraction peak measured at half-maximum intensity (full-width at half-maximum, fwhm) corrected for instrumental broadening, and θh is the angle of the particular hkl reflection. Raman spectrum was recorded on a Renishaw RM–1000 with excitation from the 514 nm line of an Ar–ion laser with a power of about 5 mW. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra measurements were carried out on a NICOLET 380 Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a PHI quantera SXM spectrometer with an Al Kα = 280.00 eV excitation source, where binding energies were calibrated by referencing the C 1s peak (284.8 eV) to reduce the sample charge effect. The morphology of as-prepared product was studied by using transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN electron microscope, operating at 200 kV). The N2 sorption isotherms were measured on NOVA 1000e surface area and poresize analyzer (Quantachrome Instrument, USA) at 77 K. From the adsorption branch of isotherm curves in the P/P 0 range between 0.05 and 0.35, the specific surface areas (S BET) of Co@CoO x @C-XX are calculated by the multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore size distribution was evaluated by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model. The total pore volume (V total) was determined from the amount adsorbed at the relative pressure of about 0.99. For the analysis of the magnetic material of the hysteresis loop used for the PPMS-9T-type physical magnetic test system, the temperature was 300 K, and the magnetic field strength is −40–40 kOe, plus field cooling (FC) and zero field cooling (ZFC) response curve (magnetic field 100 Oe). Elemental analysis (EA) is The Thermo Flash EA 1112.

The microstructures of Co-MOF, Co-MOF-GO, Co-MOF-PVP, and Co-MOF-PVP-GO precursors were observed by TEM images (Figure S3). Co-MOF showed uniform flake-like and somewhat curled up together (Figure S3a,b). In Co-MOF-GO, flakes curled up together and covered uniformly on GO sheets (Figure S3c,d). Co-MOF-PVP also showed sheet-like because PVP prevented MOF from curling and maintained the flake shape (Figure S3e,f). Co-MOF-PVP-GO sheets covered uniformly on GO (Figure S3g,h). These MOFs precursors were used as catalysts for hydrogen generation from hydrolysis of NaBH4 (Figure S4a). Different MOFs composites exhibited somewhat catalytic activity for hydrogen generation with various moderate reaction rates. There was little positive effect on catalytic activity with NaOH (Figure S4b). In the reaction process, the MOFs composites gradually turned into black powder with significant magnetism due to the reduction effect of NaBH4. The XRD pattern of used composites presented the diffraction peaks at 44.2°, 51.5°, and 75.9°, corresponding to ferromagnetic Co(0) (Figure S4c). To obtain catalytic materials with higher activity, the thermal pyrolysis of MOFs precursors through annealing treatment should be necessary. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of Co-MOF-GO was performed in air and Ar atmosphere to demonstrate 700 °C as appropriate annealing temperature ().

The surface composition of four composites was determined by XPS spectra. The C 1s peaks in Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG corresponded to CC (284.4 eV), C–O (285.05 eV), and OC (288.7 eV) bonds (a,b). The peaks of C–O and OC were very weak, which exhibited that GO is partially reduced during the solvothermal process. The possible formation of interfacial C–O–Co bonds is also suggested, which is responsible for anchoring CoO x . The O 1s peaks of Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG were divided into the CoO (529.69 eV), C–O (530.0 eV), and OC (532.74 eV), which proved that Co became CoO x after 200 °C at air (c,d). The main peaks centered at 285 eV, 530 eV, and 778–798 eV are attributed to C 1s, O 1s, and Co 2p in Co@CoO x @CG, respectively (g,h). The N 1s peak in Co@CoO x @N-CG is centered at 402 eV (h). The weak N 1s peak in Co@CoO x @N-CG accounts for the small amount of N in composite (Figure S8a,b). In Co@CoO x @C and Co@CoO x @N–C, it is similar to each other (e and S9a). The EA perfectly echoed the Raman and XPS spectra. The TGA curves of composites were measured in air atmosphere (Figure S10). The mass ratios of Co were calculated as 72%, 62%, 75%, and 67% for Co@CoO x @C, Co@CoO x @CG, Co@CoO x @N–C, and Co@CoO x @N-CG, respectively. By EA, the mass ratios of Co were calculated as 89%, 58%, 83%, and 64% for Co@CoO x @C, Co@CoO x @CG, Co@CoO x @N–C, and Co@CoO x @N-CG, respectively (Table S1). The relative atomic ratio proved that C is the main component, and Co is very little in surface, due to the core–shells structure (Table S2).

The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG were measured by at 77 K (). The S BET values of 67 and 46 m2 g–1 were obtained for Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG with pore volumes of 0.2 and 0.1 cm3 g–1 between 15 and 300 nm. Such large specific surface areas were of importance for enhancing the catalyst activity. These textural properties were comparable to those of typical catalysts.

The magnetization curves of Co@CoO x @CG were measured at 300 K in a variable applied field (a). The hysteresis loop of Co@CoO x @CG showed a coercive force (H c) of 480.97 Oe and remanent magnetization (M r) of 446.46 emu g–1 with a S r = M r/H c value of 0.93. These parameters were evidence for the ferromagnetism of Co@CoO x @CG (Figure S11). The ferromagnetism properties with strong magnetic response make Co@CoO x @CG are easily isolated from water mixing system (Figure S12). The ZFC and FC magnetization curves of Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG were measured with an applied field of 500 Oe (c,d). The Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG showed ferromagnetic properties in 2–219.4 K and 2–215.3 K due to the existence of ferromagnetic Co. In ZFC curves, Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG reached the maximum magnetization at 219.4 and 215.3 K, respectively. The weak temperature dependence of magnetism ensures Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG be easily used in a wide temperature range. The Co@CoO x @C and Co@CoO x @N–C showed similar performances (Figure S12).

Through linear slopes, the reaction activation energy values were calculated as 23.3, 25.8, 40.0, and 36.6 kJ mol–1 for Co@CoO x @C, Co@CoO x @N–C, Co@CoO x @CG, and Co@CoO x @N-CG, respectively.

The high r B values of 2140, 2435, 5560, and 3270 mL min–1 gCo –1 were calculated for Co@CoO x @C, Co@CoO x @N–C, Co@CoO x @CG, and Co@CoO x @N-CG at 303 K, respectively (a). With Co@CoO x @CG as optimized catalyst, the highest r B value of 17360 mL min–1 gCo –1 can be obtained at an elevated temperature of 328 K. The catalytic activity of Co@CoO x @CG and Co@CoO x @N-CG also exhibited obvious advantages compared to those of Co@CG and Co@N-CG at various temperatures (b). These catalytic activities are comparable to those in the literature (Table S3). The existences of CoO x shells, rGO sheets, and N-doping atoms in composites do improve the catalytic activity of composites due to the synergistic effect (a,b). Two composites showed excellent recyclability, even if being reused for five times, and the catalytic activity did not fade drastically (c,d). The composition and phase structure also were maintained well after being used (Figure S17). The weak decreasing catalytic activity of reused catalysts is mainly caused by the separation treatment in air atmosphere. These excellent catalytic properties ensure that the multilayer core–shells on sheets composites can be applied into some other reactions such as oxygen evolution reaction or oxygen reduction reaction. Generally, the thickness of shells in core–shell structures has a significant effect on catalytic activity due to the diffusion restriction in thick shells. The shell thick tuning will be studied in future work.
